summary: This is a protective order issued by Judge Alison J. Nathan in the criminal case against Ghislaine Maxwell. The order establishes strict rules for handling discovery materials produced by the government, which include sensitive, confidential, and highly confidential information such as personal identifying details of victims and witnesses, and nude or sexualized images. The order aims to protect privacy, prevent prejudicial pretrial publicity, and safeguard the ongoing investigation.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant in the criminal case (20 Cr. 330) for which this protective order is issued. The order governs how she and her defense team can use and disclose discovery materials provided by the government.

persons.name: Alison J. Nathan
persons.context: The judge presiding over the case who issued this protective order.

connections.description: Judge Nathan is the presiding judicial officer over the criminal case in which Maxwell is the defendant.

events.title: Issuance of Protective Order
events.description: Judge Alison J. Nathan signs and issues a protective order governing the handling of discovery materials in the criminal case against Ghislaine Maxwell.

keyFacts: The government's discovery materials in the Ghislaine Maxwell case contain sensitive information affecting privacy, details that could impede an ongoing investigation, and risk prejudicial pretrial publicity.
The discovery includes 'Highly Confidential Information' defined as containing 'nude, partially-nude, or otherwise sexualized images, videos, or other depictions of individuals.'

The protective order strictly limits who can access the materials (defendant, defense counsel, designated experts/staff, potential witnesses) and imposes rules against public disclosure, internet posting, and filing in public records.
The defendant, Ghislaine Maxwell, is only allowed to review certain confidential materials in the presence of her defense counsel or via secured electronic access provided by the Bureau of Prisons.
The order acknowledges the existence of victims and witnesses whose identities are to be protected unless they have already identified themselves publicly on the record.
